text:
WA, Pilbara Block, Balmoral Project, magnetic surveys. 
 1  Maps 
 3 
 Appendices 
 0 
 5  Table Nos: 
 Exploration licence 47/1121 forms part of the Balmoral project area, 
 which consists of 19 tenements over the western parts of the Pilbara 
 Craton of Western Australia. The tenement was granted on the 28th 
 February 2003. 
 Diamond  exploration  conducted  by  De  Beers  Australia  Exploration 
 Limited  (DBAE)  during  the  third  year  of  tenure  included  the 
 reassessment of all results and the identification of gaps in the sample 
 coverage. This allowed an area to be defined for third year compulsory 
 drop off.  
 The  entire  tenement  was  to  be  re-flown  east-west  by  airborne 
 magnetics  during  the  2005  field  season.  Previous  aeromagnetic 
 surveying  was  flown  north-south  which  possibly  contributed  to  the 
 lack  of  discrimination  of  the  north-south Yanyare  dyke  in  the  survey 
 data.  However  due  to  the  lack  of  availability  of  airborne  magnetic 
 systems  the  surveying  was  delayed  until  the  1st  of  February  where 
 further  delays  were  experienced  through  cyclone  activity  in  the 
 Pilbara. The survey is expected to be flown in May 2006.

11.text: Diamond exploration activities conducted by De Beers Australia Exploration

12.text: Limited (DBAE) during the third year of tenure involved the reassessment of

13.text: heavy  mineral,  results  and  the  partial  relinquishment  of  50%  of  the

14.text: tenement. In addition the tenement was to be re-flown with east-west line

15.text: spacing in an attempt to locate other north-south linear features responsible

16.text: for the distribution kimberlitic type indicator minerals.

text:
Diamond exploration activities conducted by De Beers Australia Exploration 
 Limited (DBAE) during the third year of tenure involved the reassessment of 
 heavy  mineral,  results  and  the  partial  relinquishment  of  50%  of  the 
 tenement. In addition the tenement was to be re-flown with east-west line 
 spacing in an attempt to locate other north-south linear features responsible 
 for the distribution kimberlitic type indicator minerals.

48.text: CPTZ has been interpreted by Van Kranendonk (2002) as a deformation and

49.text: granite  intrusion  zone  developed  from  a  post  3300Ma  rifting  of  the  East

50.text: Pilbara Granite Greenstone Terrane. Deposition in this zone gave rise to the

51.text: Mallina Basin defined by the strike slip faulting to the north and south. The

 Mallina Basin defined by the strike slip faulting to the north and south. The

33.text: The tenement, E47/1121, lies above the coastal plains in the low rolling

34.text: hills of the Fortescue plain. The tenement drained by the northerly flowing

35.text: headwaters of the Yanyare River, Devil Creek and Armstrong Creek and to

36.text: the south by the southerly Fortescue Rover tributary, Tanga Tanga Creek.

 The tenement, E47/1121, lies above the coastal plains in the low rolling 
 hills of the Fortescue plain. The tenement drained by the northerly flowing 
 headwaters of the Yanyare River, Devil Creek and Armstrong Creek and to 
 the south by the southerly Fortescue Rover tributary, Tanga Tanga Creek.  
 (after  A.M.Thorne and A.F.Trendall 2001) 
 The project area is dominated by the Fortescue Group, a thick sequence of 
 Archaean  mafic  and  felsic  volcanic  piles  and  associated  sedimentary  rocks 
 that unconformably overly the Archaean Pilbara Craton granite-greenstones. 
 The area straddles the West Pilbara Granite-Greenstone Terrane (WPGGT) 
 and  the  Central  Pilbara  Tectonic  Zone  (CPTZ).  The  WPGGT  is  dominated 
 by north-easterly trending granitoid complexes, discordant greenstone belts

18.text: The geology within the tenement E47/1121 comprises mainly exposures of

19.text: Kylena Formation and minor exposures of the Tumbiana and Maddina Forma-

20.text: tions. The Kylena Formation which outcrops through the centre of the tene-

21.text: ment conformably overlies the Hardy Formation and comprises mainly amyg-

22.text: daloidal and massive basalt flows. The Tumbiana Formation is exposed in the

23.text: western  part  of  the  tenement,  and  conformably  overlies  the Kylena  Forma-

24.text: tion.  It  contains  mainly  coastal  and  near-shore  facies  sedimentary  rocks

25.text: ranging from stromatolitic and clastic carbonates, argillite, sandstone, pri-

26.text: mary  and  reworked  tuff  and  minor  conglomerate;  with  a  minor  mafic  lava

27.text: component. The  Maddina  Formation  which  occurs  to  the  very  west  of  the

28.text: tenement area comprises mainly basalt flows, pillow lavas, fine- to coarse-

29.text: grained  and  mafic  volcanic  rocks.  Non-volcanic  sedimentary  rocks  include

30.text: stromatolitic  carbonate,  quartz  sandstone,  conglomerate  and  argillite. The

31.text: geology also includes outcrops of the Cooya Pooya Dolerite and the Cher-

32.text: rata Granitiod. The  Cooya  Pooya  Dolerite  is  a  large  sill  complex  which  in-

33.text: trudes the middle part of the Hardy Formation and along the Hardy-Kylena

34.text: Formation boundary. Both intrusive sills have metamorphosed the surround-

35.text: ing country rock. The Cheratta Granitiod (c. 3130-2944Ma) contains a va-

36.text: riety of granitic rocks, including some small inliers of tonalite and outcrops

37.text: in  the  eastern  part  of  the  tenement. The  tenement  is  also  cross-cut  with

38.text: several regional-scale NE trending dolerite dykes and faults.

47.text: relinquishment. In addition 1:50,000 drainage base maps were purchased

text:
units encountered are the pre-Mount Roe sedimentary units, the Mount Roe 
 Basalts,  the  Hardey  Formation  sedimentary  and  felsic  to  mafic  volcanic 
 units,  the  Kylena  Basalts,  Tumbiana  volcanoclastics  and  associated 
 sediments,  the  Maddina  Basalts  and  the  Jeerinah  Formation  volcanics  and 
 associated  sediments.  The  Fortescue  Group  is  overlain  by  the  Hamersley 
 Group,  in  the  project  area  this  group  is  represented  predominately  by  the 
 Marra  Mamba  and  Brockman  Iron  Formations.  Numerous  minor  intrusions 
 are  found  within  the  Fortescue  and  Hamersley  Groups,  mainly  mafic  sills 
 and  dykes.  Young  Tertiary  surfaces  are  preserved  as  outliers  of  Robe 
 Pisolite and other ferruginous sedimentary units. 
 The geology within the tenement E47/1121 comprises mainly exposures of 
 Kylena Formation and minor exposures of the Tumbiana and Maddina Forma-
 tions. The Kylena Formation which outcrops through the centre of the tene-
 ment conformably overlies the Hardy Formation and comprises mainly amyg-
 daloidal and massive basalt flows. The Tumbiana Formation is exposed in the 
 western  part  of  the  tenement,  and  conformably  overlies  the Kylena  Forma-
 tion.  It  contains  mainly  coastal  and  near-shore  facies  sedimentary  rocks 
 ranging from stromatolitic and clastic carbonates, argillite, sandstone, pri-
 mary  and  reworked  tuff  and  minor  conglomerate;  with  a  minor  mafic  lava 
 component. The  Maddina  Formation  which  occurs  to  the  very  west  of  the 
 tenement area comprises mainly basalt flows, pillow lavas, fine- to coarse-
 grained  and  mafic  volcanic  rocks.  Non-volcanic  sedimentary  rocks  include 
 stromatolitic  carbonate,  quartz  sandstone,  conglomerate  and  argillite. The 
 geology also includes outcrops of the Cooya Pooya Dolerite and the Cher-
 rata Granitiod. The  Cooya  Pooya  Dolerite  is  a  large  sill  complex  which  in-
 trudes the middle part of the Hardy Formation and along the Hardy-Kylena 
 Formation boundary. Both intrusive sills have metamorphosed the surround-
 ing country rock. The Cheratta Granitiod (c. 3130-2944Ma) contains a va-
 riety of granitic rocks, including some small inliers of tonalite and outcrops 
 in  the  eastern  part  of  the  tenement. The  tenement  is  also  cross-cut  with 
 several regional-scale NE trending dolerite dykes and faults.  
 4.1  Sample Results Reassessment 
 During the reporting period all results from the heavy mineral sampling were 
 reassessed  in  preparation  of  the  compulsory  50%  3rd  year  partial 
 relinquishment. In addition 1:50,000 drainage base maps were purchased 
 and the sampling density was reassessed to identify areas not covered by the 
 existing  sampling  coverage.  Several  catchment  areas  have  been  identified

 5.  CONCLUSION AND FORWARD WORK PROGRAMME 
 Diamond  exploration  conducted  by  De  Beers Australia  Exploration  Limited 
 (DBAE) during the third year of tenure included the reassessment of results 
 from  the  heavy  mineral  and  drill  samples  taken  in  the  two  years  of  tenure 
 and the planning of an airborne magnetic survey over the entire tenement. 
 The planned aeromagnetic survey has been delayed three times, initially by 
 the lack of availability of airborne systems and secondly by several cyclones 
 in the Pilbara and finally by aircraft failure.  
 Proposed field work for the upcoming field season includes the follow-up to 
 the  samples  identified  during  reassessment  and  infill  sampling  the 
 catchments identified as being ineffectively unsampled.  The aeromagnetic 
 data  will  be  processed  for  the  identification  of  intrusive  signatures  for 
 follow-up  by  ground  inspection,  heavy  mineral  and  rock  sampling  and
